Judul: EVALUATION OF OXYGEN BEHAVIOR IN OVERBURDEN DUMPING AREA: A FIELD MEASUREMENT STUDY COMPARING POTENTIALLY ACID FORMING AND NON-ACID FORMING ROCK
Abstrak:
Sulfide mineral oxidation within coal-bearing rock is fundamental reaction that determines acid mine drainage
(AMD) generation in the coal mine. Pyrite, as a prominent sulfide mineral due to its reactivity and abundance, is
easily exposed in the overburden dumping area which causes this area becomes the great source of AMD
pollution in mine site after the oxidation takes place. In order to reduce AMD generation, numerous prevention
methods are studied and applied in the overburden dumping area by cutting off one or both of the reactanis:
oxygen and water. Prevalent prevention method in the coal mine site is dry cover technigue that segregate the
potentially acid forming (PAF) and non-acid forming (NAF) rock, then encapsulate PAF underneath NAF
therefore minimize infiltration of reactanis.

Oxygen plays important role for efficiency of dry cover technigue in overburden dumping. As the result, its
behavior is widely studied to understand reaction process that happen in this area thus obtain the most effective
prevention for AMD. This research aims to evaluate oxygen behavior of dry cover, in both PAF and NAF layer,
for understanding the effect of sulfide oxidation and oxygen consumption rate. Two different depths of one drill
hole for each PAF and NAF rock layer were investigated. Oxygen and moisture then were measured Jor around
24 hours. Static tests for acid producing capacity (Total Sulfur test, Acid Neutralizing Capacity test and Net Acid
Generating test) were carried out to investigate the correlation of sulfide oxidation and oxygen consumption in
the field.
